channel.title: Blog on Home
channel.description: Recent content in Blog on Home

item.title: Man-in-the-Middle
item.description: A man-in-the-middle (MITM) attack is a network security attack where a malicious device enters a network and intercepts traffic between nodes or components. To accomplish access to a network an attacker needs an entry point. There are many ways for a malicious device to accomplish access into a network.

item.title: React vs Flutter
item.description: The big trade off between Flutter and React is: web support vs spread operator Sound silly? Let me elaborate… flutter / dart The main advantage here is web support. With react the mobile and web components are not compatible without some experimental library to translate them.

item.title: modd: daemon for reloading
item.description: One of my favourite tools now is modd. Why is it so great? It does one job, and it does it well, in proper unix fashion. Monitoring a file-system and running a daemon that reloads if anything changes. Also in proper Unix fashion, the daemon is sent a configurable SIGHUP when a file changes.

item.title: Audit
item.description: Have removed some incomplete content that was incomplete or did not make sense anymore. The URL’s are now aliased here for reference.

item.title: Alternate Keyboard
item.description: Decided to switch to using a alternate keyboard layout, not too long ago…. Well I guess it has been a couple of years now. But I love it. Always heard about others using the Dvorak keyboard layout and thought, “boy that is really neat, but too much work to change”.

item.title: Old Demos
item.description: Found an old demo of an App from 2010. Brings back fond memories of hacking away to The Resistance by Muse. You can still get an updated version on the app store.

item.title: Rubber Ducking
item.description: Yes, rubber duck debugging is really funny (post it on quack overflow!). The wiki, a dedicated site or coding horror explain it pretty well. It is a fantastic methodology because there is no other human to try and take advantage of your stupidity - implicitly (unconsciously) or explicitly (capitalism).

item.title: Blockchain Mesh Networks
item.description: Using the blockchain mesh network routers allow freedom and payments. The underlying core of bitcoin, the blockchain is a system that can be applied to a variety of uses. One particular disruptive use, that is not mentioned on the wiki, is mesh networks.

item.title: Innovation Illusions - SRED the Evidence
item.description: Most of the software industry in Canada is fueled by the Scientific Research and Experimental Development Program. Every job I have ever worked has used it, most quite extensively. The program is basically is looking for innovation in Canada. Proving time spent advancing an uncertainty, such as researching or doing experimental development, earns you benefits.

item.title: Software Methodologies
item.description: At the end of the day, software methodologies are all some form of Development Lifecycle. That is to say, the individuals unit of work, the team’s unit of work and the business, are in one of several stages. Requirements and Planning Analysis and Design Implementation Testing and Verification Deployment and Maintenance That is it.

item.title: Hybrid Schemaless Databases
item.description: TL;DR - Hydrid relational schemaless databases are quite awesome, with a little bit flowers in the garden. True schemaless databases came into my radar with MongoDB, Redis and such. I have often admired the ability to alter schema on fly and enjoyed experimenting with the possibilities.

item.title: why golang
item.description: Have become a fan boy of golang as a replacement for my beloved C purely because it is so simplified, and thus a guru language to me. As it stands now, I am somewhat burned out in the depths of a mid-life crisis and pandemic.

item.title: why golang
item.description: Have become a fan boy of golang as a replacement for my beloved C purely because it is so simplified, and thus a guru language to me. As it stands now, I am somewhat burned out in the depths of a mid-life crisis and pandemic.

item.title: Git Notes Storage
item.description: Am working on a project build tool to make repeatable tasks for Micrantha projects easier. A module of this tool is automatic versioning using semantic version. The versioning The way I wanted the versioning to work is to have thresholds for when a version component auto-increments.

item.title: Mirroring git with jenkins
item.description: Introduction For some software development projects, there may be a need to backup or mirror the repository to a different location. Jenkins or other continuous integration (CI) can automate this. This log is a brief summary of how in case I need to reproduce.

item.title: A self hosting journey
item.description: Introduction Would like to say that I have valid privacy or security concerns. Or because it can be done better. But the reality is, I just want to self host because I can. Where to start? The awesome self hosted page lists just about every cloud service I use with a replaceable near-quality solution, if your willing to sacrifice a bit for it.

item.title: Favourite 'nixisms
item.description: Introduction A log to myself of things I like about Unix type systems. In case I forget why someday. Dotfiles files in braille? are they for the blind?Dotfiles in Linux are hidden files preceded with a period. Depending on the program, they are used for configuration in your home directory.

item.title: Futurism - Tech and Humanity
item.description: A work in progressIntroduction The nanotechnology summary goes like this: it is a technology that works are the nano scale (1 billionth of a metre). To put it in perspective, it takes 10 hydrogen atoms side by side to equal 1 nanometre.

item.title: Mitmproxy and Android
item.description: Introduction Debugging network traffic for your app can be useful, and sometimes necessary if the data is not what is expected or inconsistent. The Proxy I prefer the open source proxy [mitmproxy](https://mitmproxy.org =300x203). Easy to install on OSX with homebrew.

item.title: Fortunes on Slack
item.description: view the service homepage Introduction Have always enjoyed the UNIX fortunes program, ever since I was a wee newbie. If you aren’t familiar with it (sad), yes, its like a fortune cookie. It can be more technical in nature but not always.

item.title: OpenAPI Directory & Swagger
item.description: Was browsing github and I came across the OpenAPI Directory. A good directory of API’s will help in thinking of a mobile app idea. Couldn’t help but notice that all the API’s implement something called OpenAPI ("Swagger") 2.0. Ok, great, consistency in API specs, that will help if you had to write one.

item.title: post to facebook from command line
item.description: Wrote a small script to make a post on facebook. Could be extended to post to twitter or anything else ifttt.com supports.

item.title: Textman Part 1
item.description: a ascii art hero, who has amazing adventures and solves interesting problems. Dev Log The initial implementation sees an animatable ascii art hero that can walk and jump. The engine is a simple entity based system with rendering done on the curses library.

item.title: Elixir and Phoenix
item.description: Introduction If you dont know phoenix framework, I’d describe it as rails for elixir. If you dont know Elixir I’d describe it as a functional language that feels like ruby for erlang. If you don’t know erlang it has been around a while (open-sourced in 1998) and the virtual machine is designed to be highly fault tolerant and scalable for use in telecoms, banking and instant messaging (WhatsApp).

item.title: Yahtsee
item.description: Introducing an unabashedly self-indulgent project Yahtsee. Play the classic dice game from your terminal. It’s even multi-player on-line! Strategically not named Yahtzee to avoid lawsuits! Admittedly I only built it to demo/test app the networking features of my libarg3 library. Its smart enough to open a port on your UPnP enabled router though.

item.title: Manual Testing With Testmanship
item.description: There are still times when we are forced to test manually. I could not find cheap, easy to use software for this kind of thing, usually defaulting to an excel or word document. I’ve started testmanship.com to see if I can breathe new life into manual testing and hopefully give it more visibility to teams.

item.title: Java Key Path Json Objects
item.description: After using apple’s key-value coding to basically have models without writing models, I decided to write rewrite a simple wrapper for java’s JSONObject that will allow similar functionality. I’m aware that this method and apple’s key value coding has a performance cost.

item.title: Mud Harbour: An Experiment in Websockets and Java Web Frameworks
item.description: Well I spent some time put a web front end to some java code I made a long time ago for a MUD The project is a decent example of Jersey, SocialAuth and WebSockets with some other nifty things (taken from other frameworks - like flash messages).

item.title: Social Story Telling
item.description: Do you remember that game you played when you were young? The one where one person would say something, and it gets passed around until its a completely new story? Over the holidays, I came up with an idea for a web app that essentially does the same thing but in the context of creating a story.

item.title: Tired of Version Control Commit Messages?
item.description: Ran across this absurd version control commit message generator message generator. Even has a plugin for the best code editor around Sublime Text 2. The api is a simple index.txt for scripting: ``python req = urllib2.Request(‘http://whatthecommit.com/index.txt') res = urllib2.urlopen(req, timeout=5) message = res.

item.title: Best Programming Quotes
item.description: Quotes that relate to software engineering always humble me with their laser-like honesty. I’ve decided to keep a collection of my favorites here (in no particular order).
